ContactFormSubmission.title: ContactFormSubmission
ContactFormSubmission.description: Represents a contact form submission from the website.

id.description: Unique identifier for the contact form submission.

name.description: The name of the person submitting the form.

email.description: The email address of the person submitting the form.

company.description: The company name provided in the form.

message.description: The message content from the contact form.

submissionDate.description: The date and time the form was submitted.

CallRequest.title: CallRequest
CallRequest.description: Represents a request for a call back from a potential client.

id.description: Unique identifier for the call request.

name.description: The name of the person requesting the call.

email.description: The email address of the person requesting the call.

phone.description: The phone number of the person requesting the call.

submissionDate.description: The date and time the request was submitted.

definition.description: Stores contact form submissions.  No denormalized authorization fields are needed because access will be managed via a separate admin role system (DBAC).

params.name: submissionId
params.description: Unique identifier for the contact form submission.

definition.description: Stores call back requests from potential clients.

params.name: requestId
params.description: Unique identifier for the call request.

firestore.reasoning: This design prioritizes security and scalability for handling contact form submissions. All submissions are stored in a single collection, `/contact_form_submissions`, making listing submissions straightforward. No authorization dependencies exist as the dashboard will likely require admin access, which will be implemented out-of-scope using a separate authentication and role management system, as per the DBAC principle (Database Authentication and Authorization). This allows for future expansion without impacting the core security model of contact form submissions. The structure is simple and avoids any complex authorization rules, enabling efficient queries and updates.
